project.name: Daria Research of Researchers
project.description: We are researching how user researchers conduct discovery activities and plan for user research, from awareness and identifying research questions to research design, execution, analysis, and delivery.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Hello, Jesse. I'm fine. How are you?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Hey, Steven. How's it going? I'm doing great.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Thank you for participating in my research.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Of course. Happy to be on this end of it.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Yeah, it's been interesting. I'm going to try to keep my researcher mask on all the way through. And then at the very end.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: But it is difficult. It's kind of funny. But so let me start, Jesse, do I have your permission to take a transcript and a recording of the interview today.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Of course.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay. Can you tell me a little bit about your current role and how long you've had it?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, so my current role is experience strategist. I switched over into that in… 2002, so I guess it's going on three years here that I've been there. Before that, I was a UX designer Here at Deloitte.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And all of that, both when I was UX designer and when I was now as experienced strategist, really leaned into research and I would say most people at Deloitte think I'm a researcher.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Good, good. So how did you get into the research? You started with the UX. What was your migration into the research and what attracted you to that?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, I went to a master's program that was like human factors mixed with an MBA. And so learned a lot of research methods, learned a lot about human centered design and research being a big, big piece of that.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: So that all kind of started, I went to school for it, but I also worked a job before that was focused on getting like kids into architecture careers and putting people in the center of solutions in that context.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Kind of got me into human-centered design that I now apply here digitally.

entries.text: Okay, that sounds good. With respect to your current role as a strategist and researcher, what is your primary goal?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Ooh.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Surprising people surprising people uh… information that they really that was right in front of their face all the time, but never really made sense to them.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay. Are there any frustrations that happen when you're trying to do that?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Helpful.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Um… Yes. I think there's a very… I think there's a very human desire in a lot of scenarios to like default to what you know and not really allow yourself to think um in the abstract in the abstract to like imagine a world not rooted in what you already know and what constraints you already know.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: That gets in the way all the time.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Are there any key principles that you've adopted along your path?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Oh, these are big questions, Stephen. Key principles.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I mean, I definitely think integrity is a huge key principle, like making sure that you're just that you believe everything that you're presenting is, I think, a huge huge part of what like makes me okay with the work that we do a lot of the time.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, I don't know. I've never like formalized my principles

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Hmm. Typically, it's an approval like it's in putting together a plan and like explaining it to people and getting people on board with it and making edits.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Because especially with a lot of the tools that we have, once it's approved and you're ready to go, you can get results in a couple days in a week.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: You usually have to spend a couple of weeks getting approval, talking to people, making sure the test is right.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, that sounds good. Now, what do you think in the future, like three years from now, what do you think your tools and your research environment is going to look like?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Ooh, yeah. That's a great question. I think there will be a lot more, I think, automated synthesis will be a lot better.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Right now, it's really unreliable and not very good. I think in three years, they'll get a lot better at it.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I think there will always there will be a better push in the tools that we use towards a centralized insights repository or a sense of… Like insights understanding database thing Because I think ideally what we're moving towards is You run studies, you find things out, but then you could also start posing questions to your research base and get some findings back, which Baymart already kind of does a little bit. They have like an AI integration tool where it's like.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Hey, like maybe we haven't posted an article, but ask us a question and they'll pull up relevant articles to that question or they'll even give an AI generated kind of take on your question.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I think that will be more specific to like research that we've done in the past, right? And how people will respond to things and Maybe getting into a question that you didn't explicitly ask, but it can still have provide an opinion on.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, that's good.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: So can you think of a story in your time in recent research, the last two years or so, that you had a project that looked like it was going to be just brain dead and easy, but no matter what happened, it became frustrating and just a struggle.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: And ended up having a kind of a hard ending.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah. I did a… project with Marriott one time where we were trying to understand more about card members.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And it was like, we put in like a lot of work for this. We wanted to interview like 15 people and it was like $5,000 to source them. It was a survey that was just like a screener survey that was just not very complex and then like.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Interviewing for 15 people like to get that level of detail that we did end up getting. I didn't actually end up conducting the interview someone else did but that was just like a slog. It was like, oh my gosh, all we need to do is talk to 15 people like

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Why is this taking like a month and a half? And why is it so expensive?

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, now on the other end, can you think of a project that surprised you and had a happy ending and things just fell into place?

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Correctly.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, my favorite. So we have MUIQ access now. Our main stakeholder here at Spectrum one day on a Friday was like… What's people's experience like with going from a third party affiliate site to our site?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, it really depends on who I'm working with. But I'll give the example for Spectrum. We have a really solid design team. So we'll host a research question ideation session that's an hour long.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Or we'll look at any designs that have been put together. The current experience will pull all those screenshots into a fig jam.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And we'll walk through them one at a time. We'll call out, hey, do you think this works? Do you have questions about this? Like, does this make sense to do?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Sometimes we have to circle back with product on requirements. Sometimes it leads directly to a new task or something that we want to test So we'll build out the like landscape of what we want to find out first and then pull that into a test plan with research questions and a breakdown of like what we want to do and ask in that process.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, so do you do… more than one research plan for a discovery project.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I mean, we do a research plan for like every study and sometimes there's multiple things in a single study. But we do, yeah, I would say Pretty much we're always starting with the plan.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: So when you identify that you need to do, what are some of the types of research studies that you identified in that discovery period.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I mean, like what types of studies or what do you mean?

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Well, I guess, okay, so in the discovery session, you brainstorm and you kind of figure out what's the outcome, the kind of the solidified outcome of that session.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: It's the research questions. It's what they want to know so that we can pick what kind of study we want to do. So if they're like, oh, I actually like, I wonder if people will get hung up here.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, if we have the plan together and we get approval and there's no feedback and we don't have to present the plan multiple times, we're pretty good to go. We can get right into building the test. I usually… At least a day, usually no more than three days to build out any kind of test.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: And when you're building out a test, kind of explain that to me a little bit. What are you doing and what is your outcome? How do you know when you're done?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, so we go into the tool, we add in questions, add in options, like filter out for screeners.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: We make, you know, when questions are conditional, we add in those conditions. A big part of it is playing with the prototypes of those and trying to break it and seeing if everything is working right.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Sending it to other people to have them go through it and see if they can break it.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Yeah, all that takes about a day to three days to actually build out once you have a plan.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, and so now we're into the, how many typically participants do you target?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Ooh, that's the real question. Depends on if you want feelings or numbers.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: If it's numbers and you have a good amount of budget, you typically ask more quantitative questions where they're rating things or that you can look at charts and graphs and information after. Ideally, you're doing at least a couple hundred into a thousand range to get some real solid numbers you can rely on.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: But I don't actually really work in that space very much. I do mostly qualitative. So for a lot of what we do, we are in the like 15 to 50 participant range.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, when you're doing qualitative research, how much is it 45 minutes per person?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Then after we're done with all the interviews, we'll spend at least two days synthesizing those things. So we'll everyone's pain points, affinity map, look at those together, see what people are saying for pain points, get an idea of the volume. We'll do the same for…

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Moments that matter, design ideas, any category that we're looking at. So we spend a couple days just doing that and organizing that, seeing what people really said as a collective group.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And then we'll spend another two, three days building that out into a presentation or a deck

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, that sounds good. And then what do you generate personas or journey maps? Or what are some of your outputs once you're done

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Ooh, I love personas and journey maps. We don't really sell them anymore, which is kind of a bummer.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And I think a lot of it is people don't really have a goal or an intention with them anymore.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: But mostly we turn out like the synthesis and findings and recommendations that then can be either flipped into like a roadmap or can either be flipped into, you know, some kind of plan for like how we're going to build out and address these recommendations. So I would say roadmaps probably end up being more the final output of our findings.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: More so than personas and journeys kind of don't really do those anymore.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Sounds good. Now, are there any pitfalls in your process in the research, anything that are just like gaps or Gotcha.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Um… I mean, a big pitfall can be like people wanting to do it, but not having the infrastructure to do it. So there's been plenty. It happens a lot less nowadays. I think Ted's really kind of paved the way for us to be a lot better in this.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: We used to get clients that were like, yeah, we want to do research figure it out and they don't have a budget. They don't have a participant pool. They don't have like literally anything at all figured out for that.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And I've even been told by like development teams like I've been brought onto a project for research and then the dev team is like, oh, like good news. You don't have to do research because we can't figure it out. And it's like, okay, well, that's not good news.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I don't know what you think is good news, but… So yeah, there's definitely you run into people who don't really understand the value of user feedback or especially designers too can have kind of a little bit of an ego around what they've put together.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: And are very quick to, if you present findings or recommendations, very quick to be like, well, there was a problem with your study or there's a problem with the way that we did this at the other. So that's not actually the problem with the design. It's the problem with you.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: So that doesn't happen all the time, but there's definitely those moments where it's like.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: Okay, but like this happened, so… Maybe we can address it. Maybe not. I don't know.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Okay, that's good. I'm going to switch gears a little bit. Who do you work with? Who are your collaborators?

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: By name or by role? Yeah.

entries.speaker: Dulaney, Stephen
entries.text: Just kind of role types of people.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: I work with products Because they typically will set the requirements and research feeds really well into requirements.

entries.speaker: Banwart, Jesse
entries.text: So if there's a new thing we want to do and they have no idea where to get started, research is great to go in, talk to people, figure out what people need, and then report that back to product.
